title: Woolworths and Coles back NZ's lighter wine
text:
Mr Sheddon said the New Zealand industry, through clever marketing, had built New Zealand sauvignon blanc as a hugely popular international category in the past two decades, and there were similarities with them now being at the forefront of lower alcohol styles.

"The clever thing that New Zealand industry is doing is better managing things in the vineyard and production,'' Mr Sheddon said.

One of the bigger sellers in the past couple of weeks had been a Giesen Pure Light sauvignon blanc, with an alcohol content of 9.5 per cent, he said.

"Moderation'' was a big trend in the alcohol segment generally, along with premiumisation, as drinkers traded up to higher-priced offerings and drank less of them.

Dan Murphy's and its stablemate are part of the Endeavour Drinks business run by Woolworths, which in July announced a big shake-up by combining those liquor chains with ALH Group into a $10 billion business. It then intends spinning it off next year through a demerger, initial public offering or trade sale.

Other companies that are part of the lighter wines push include Accolade Wines, owned by private equity giant Carlyle Group, Spy Valley Wines, Wither Hills, Villa Maria and Allan Scott Wines. Varieties include sauvignon blanc, pinot gris and rose′.

Coles, through its First Choice and Liquorland stores, is also getting behind the lighter wines push.

Dr David Jordan, the program manager for NZ Lighter Wines, said the New Zealand grape growing climate meant that it had a head start.

Advertisement

"We have an advantage already,'' Dr Jordan said.

He said customers were embracing the lower alcohol wines because they retained the full flavour and taste of higher alcohol content varieties.

"The full-strength equivalent would sit anywhere between 13 to 14.5 per cent,'' he said.

He said the reduction in alcohol level was between 25 to 30 per cent.

The beer industry in Australia had been a pioneer in introducing mid-strength and lower alcohol varieties and New Zealand wine producers aimed to replicate the success using lower alcohol wines.

"Australia has already been in this space with beer,'' Dr Jordan said.

Figures from industry body Wine Australia show that over the past 20 years, New Zealand wine exports to Australia have risen from 2.7 million litres to 56.5 million litres, with a large part of it stemming from sauvignon blanc from the Marlbough region.

New Zealand wine represents 56 per cent of Australia's total wine imports.

Advertisement

The 18 New Zealand producers aim to capture a 10 per cent market share of the global market between 2025 to 2030.

While most of the wines are centred on white wine varieties, Forrest Wines has been able to make a Pinot Noir with an alcohol content of 9.5 per cent.

Mainstream beer consumption in Australia is at 70-year lows, although the craft beer segment is growing strongly at between 15 to 20 per cent.
description: Eighteen Kiwi wineries are cutting alcohol levels by up to 30 per cent in some varieties in a 'lighter wine' push that's taking off in Australia.
